text.0: thou agni wast the earliest aṅgiras a seer thou wast a god thyself the gods auspicious friend.
text.1: after thy holy ordinance the maruts sage active through wisdom with their glittering spears were born.
text.2: o agni thou the best and earliest aṅgiras fulfillest as a sage the holy law of gods.
text.3: sprung from two mothers wise through all existence spread resting in many a place for sake of living man.
text.4: to mātariśvan first thou agni wast disclosed and to vivasvān through thy noble inward power.
text.5: heaven and earth vasu shook at the choosing of the priest the burthen thou didst bear didst worship mighty gods.
text.6: agni thou madest heaven to thunder for mankind thou yet more pious for pious purūravas.
text.7: when thou art rapidly freed from thy parents first eastward they bear thee round and after to the west.
text.8: thou agni art a bull who makes our store increase to be invoked by him who lifts the ladle up.
text.9: well knowing the oblation with the hallowing word uniting all who live thou lightenest first our folk.
text.10: agni thou savest in the synod when pursued een him farseeing one who walks in evil ways.
text.11: thou when the heroes fight for spoil which men rush round slayest in war the many by the hands of few.
text.12: for glory agni day by day thou liftest up the mortal man to highest immortality.
text.13: even thou who yearning for both races givest them great bliss and to the prince grantest abundant food.
text.14: o agni highly lauded make our singer famous that he may win us store of riches.
text.15: may we improve the rite with new performance o earth and heaven with all the gods protect us.
text.16: o blameless agni lying in thy parents lap a god among the gods be watchful for our good.
text.17: former of bodies be the singers providence all good things hast thou sown for him auspicious one.
text.18: agni thou art our providence our father thou we are thy brethren and thou art our spring of life.
text.19: in thee rich in good heroes guard of high decrees meet hundred thousand treasures o infallible.
text.20: thee agni have the gods made the first living one for living man lord of the house of nahuṣa.
text.21: iḷā they made the teacher of the sons of men what time a son was born to the father of my race.
text.22: worthy to be revered o agni god preserve our wealthy patrons with thy succours and ourselves.
text.23: guard of our seed art thou aiding our cows to bear incessantly protecting in thy holy way.
text.24: agni thou art a guard close to the pious man kindled art thou foureyed for him who is unarmed.
text.25: with fond heart thou acceptest een the poor mans prayer when he hath brought his gift to gain security.
text.26: thou agni gainest for the loudlypraising priest the highest wealth the object of a mans desire.
text.27: thou art called father caring even for the weak and wisest to the simple one thou teachest lore.
text.28: agni the man who giveth guerdon to the priests like wellsewn armour thou guardest on every side.
text.29: he who with grateful food shows kindness in his house an offerer to the living is the type of heaven.
text.30: pardon we pray this sin of ours o agnithe path which we have trodden widely straying.
text.31: dear friend and father caring for the pious who speedest nigh and who inspirest mortals.
text.32: as erst to manus to yayāti aṅgiras so aṅgiras pure agni come thou to our hall.
text.33: bring hither the celestial host and seat them here upon the sacred grass and offer what they love.
text.34: by this our prayer be thou o agni strengthened prayer made by us after our power and knowledge.
text.35: lead thou us therefore to increasing riches endow us with thy strengthbestowing favour.
